Far from mad Folly's tinsel glare,</br>When dewy Twilight veils the sky;</br>With Meditation will I share</br>The joys of calm Tranquillity.
Whilst others weave the airy dance,</br>And crown the mantling bowl with flowers,</br>Let me with solemn steps advance,</br>To Contemplation's silent bowers.
The distant curfew's dying knell,</br>Borne on the Zephyr, meets mine ear;</br>And, tumbling o'er yon rocky dell,</br>The limpid rivulet murmurs near.
Sad Philomela pours her note,</br>And binds the soul in rapture's chain;</br>Whilst Sylphids light in ether float,</br>And listen to the melting strain.
With sullen pride, its shatter'd towers,</br>O'er yonder hill, the Castle rears;</br>Ruin hath mark'd his fatal powers,</br>And Horror o'er the wreck appears.
Near those rude walls, in days of yore,</br>Bold Victory shook her wings elate;</br>Her flaming shield on high she bore,</br>And triumph'd in majestic state.
To gain fair Freedom's heavenly sway,</br>Full many a gallant Baron bled;</br>And soldiers, rang'd in bright array,</br>Their blood-stain'd banners waving spread.
Here, at the gorgeous tournament,</br>When warriors cherish'd martial fire,</br>Oft would the Bard, to pleasure bent</br>Wake the soft magic of the lyre.
Struck by whose notes, at evening hour,</br>The shepherd as he hied him home,</br>Charm'd with the Minstrel's thrilling pow'r,</br>Would hasten to the high-arch'd dome.
Oft would the fretted roofs resound,</br>With praise of glorious chivalry,</br>'Till every hero taught the sound,</br>And bade their numbers float on high.
Here too MATILDA sought repose,</br>And banish'd each intrusive fear,</br>Whilst the fair partner of her woes</br>Indulg'd the sympathetic tear.
When LEICESTER, by his Queen's command,</br>Awhile forsook this woodland seat;</br>They, by the gentlest Zephyrs fann'd,</br>Disported in the calm retreat.
E'en now I see with mental ken,</br>Those sisters fair of heavenly mien;</br>They wander thro' the silent glen,</br>Whilst Pleasure haunts the pensive scene.
But hark — the cannons thund'ring roll;</br>And the dread Queen's approach declare;</br>What pangs, MATILDA, rend thy soul,</br>What piteous wailings swell the air.
ELIZA comes — with racking pain,</br>Revenge "had gnaw'd her secret heart;"</br>Dark Jealousy had fir'd her vein,</br>And pierc'd her with envenom'd dart.
ELIZA comes — A virgin choir</br>Strew wreaths of amaranthine flowers,</br>Whilst the full organ's swelling fire,</br>Breathes sweetly thro' the Gothic towers.
Amidst that choir, sublimely bright,</br>Tho' pierc'd with grief, MATILDA shines;</br>E'en to the Empress of the night</br>Reigns glorious 'mongst the lesser signs.
But see the LADY OF THE LAKE</br>Yon gorgeous pageantry prepare;</br>The little Loves their pennons shake,</br>Light floating in the liquid air.
They waft her o'er the lucid wave,</br>Thron'd on a rainbow color'd shell;</br>And lead her to the coral cave,</br>Where the blithe sedge-crown'd NEREIDS dwell.
Veil'd by a curtain's purple shade,</br>Safe from the glance of ev'ry eye,</br>MATILDA her sweet voice display'd,</br>And wak'd the soul of Harmony.
But oh! — what pangs her breast endur'd,</br>When the Queen bade th' attendant throng</br>Draw back the curtain which obscur'd</br>The heavenly minister of song.
The veil was drawn — grim Rage stood nigh,</br>And pierc'd the Queen with with'ring glare;</br>She shrank aghast — her soul-set eye</br>Flash'd vengeance on the mournful fair.
The veil was drawn — with trembling grace</br>MATILDA wak'd the choral sound;</br>She sigh'd — she wip'd her pallid face—</br>And shivering — sunk upon the ground.
Ah!  hadst thou sunk — to rise no more,</br>Had Death's cold hand then clos'd thine eyes;</br>Ah!  had some glorious angel bore</br>Thy pure soul to its native skies—
But oh!  my heart in pity bleeds,</br>Illustrious mourner, o'er thy woe;</br>How doth it curse those fatal deeds,</br>That bade the tears of anguish flow.
Oft midst these desolated walls,</br>Thy guardian Genius wails thy doom;</br>On each avenging power she calls,</br>And frames a visionary tomb.
"Ye woodland nymphs, a wreath prepare,</br>With Spring's first flowers your tresses braid;</br>The primrose pale and lily fair,</br>Shall sooth MATILDA'S injur'd shade.
"And ye, that sit enthron'd in light,</br>With solemn harpings swell the sky;</br>MATILDA'S soul, divinely bright,</br>Shall join the grand sublimity."
But see, thro' yonder mould'ring pile</br>Pale Cynthia shoots her glimmering ray;</br>The Muse now seeks the darksome isle,</br>And pours the sadly-pleasing lay.
How chang'd the scene — black Winters storm</br>Waves the high grass that crowns the wall;</br>And red-ey'd Horror's giant form</br>Stalks rudely thro' the desert hall.
The ivy pale, shall spread its shade,</br>And twining round, each arch sustain,</br>Long as the tottering piles decay'd,</br>Look scornful on the barren plain.
Yet Grandeur here diffus'd his ray,</br>And Pleasure once her reign began;</br>Where now giant Time, with ruthless sway,</br>Laughs at the baseless hopes of man.
Still wider from his ebon wing,</br>He throws Oblivion's deepen'd shade;</br>Whilst Genius sweeps the plaintive string,</br>And mourns the wreck such pow'r has made.
Oft, o'er this solemn ruin'd scene</br>Bright Fancy drives her flaming car,</br>And Solitude, with eye serene,</br>Sits here to mark each glimm'ring star.
When Cynthia gilds the dark'ned pole,</br>Oft may I seek these tott'ring towers;</br>Such scenes sublime the heavenly soul,</br>Such scenes awake her dormant powers.</br>
